item.title: Digital Hub
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
... powered by Apple iSync & Bluetooth Technologie

Hier findest Du Näheres zu meinem 'Digital Hub', einem Apple Powerbook Titanium, powered by Mac OS X Panther. Durch die Apple-Software "iSync" - eine wirklich geniale Synchronisations-Software auf Basis SyncML - dient mir das Powerbook als zentraler 'SyncPoint', oder eben 'Digital Hub', für den Abgleich von Termin- und Adressdaten zwischen meinem privaten Sony-Ericsson P800 und meinem Business Organizer, einem Palm TungstenT. Dabei dient Bluetooth als Kommunikationsprotokoll.


...Powerbook, P800 & TungstenT

Auf dem oben dargestellten Bild ist der 'Digital Hub' mit seinen Hardware-Komponenten dargestellt. Das Herz bildet mein 15" Titanium Powerbook welches derzeit unter Mac OS X Panther, also der aktuellsten Version dieses wirklich coolen Betriebssystems, läuft.

Die beiden zu synchronisierenden PDAs bzw. Organizer sind zum einen mein privates Organizer-Handy, ein Sony-Ericsson P800, und mein mein Geschäfts-Organizer, ein Palm TungstenT.

...die Apple iApps - iSync und iCal

Die Synchronisation-Drehscheibe, also den Hub, bildet die Software "iSync" von Apple im Zusammenspiel mit den Applikationen "Adressbook" für Kontaktdaten (Standardanwendung unter Mac OS X) und "iCal" als Kalenderprogramm (auf der iLife Produktfamilie). Alle drei Anwendungen sind kostenlos.


'Digital Hub' - powered by Mac OS X, Apple iApps & Bluetooth

item.title: iPhoto Hack
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
...die eigene Panasonic DMC-FZ 10 im iPhoto Import Dialog.

Wer sich schon immer darüber geärgert hat das Apple in dem iPhoto-Dialog "Importieren" (gemeint ist der Import von Fotos einer Digicam) eine Abbildung einer absolut un-stylischen und langweiligen Standardkamera - statt der richtigen Abbildung der automatisch erkannten Kamera (vgl. Geräteerkennung von iSync - da geht es ja auch) - darstellt findest hier eine kurze Anleitung für das persönliches Customizing von iPhoto, am Beispiel der Panasonic DMC-FZ 10...

Der Stein des Anstoßes...



...besteht aus der nebenstehenden dargestellten Abbildung der absolut un-stylischen Standard-Digicam welche sich in Apples' iPhoto in dem Dialog "...Fotos von der Digicam importieren" dem Nutzer präsentiert.

...und das Ergebnis des Customizing




Die Panasonic DMC-FZ 10 in dem Import-Dialog von iPhoto

Fazit:
...klar, diese Abbildung muss weg und einer schöne Darstellung der gerade erst (teuer) erworbenen Panasonic DMC-FZ 10 weichen.

Ich werde an dieser Stelle nich weiter auf die wirklich geniale Digicam und ihre Eigenschaften eingehen - obgleich nicht nur das 12-fach Zoom mehr als einen Nebensatz verdienen würde - sondern erkläre im Folgenden wie Du die Standard-Cam gegen (irgen-) Deine Digicam austauschen kannst.

... das versprochene How-to:


Nachdem nun zum einen das Problem erkannt und die üblichen Zeilen für den Disclaimer spendiert sind kommen wir zur Lösung:

Das Ziel der nachfolgenden Bemühungen wird es sein, das iPhoto Application-Package zu öffnen und darin zwei Images - genau, diese enhalten "den Stein des Anstoßes" - auszutauschen.

Hinweis(e):
* Alle Änderungen welche Du auf Grund der nachfolgenden Beschreibung an Deiner iPhoto Applikation durchführst gehen auf Dein eigenes Risiko! Ich übernehme KEINERLEI Haftung für die weitere einwandfreie Funktionstüchtigkeit der Applikation nach dieser Anpassung - obgleich dieser marginale Hack sicherlich keinen bleibenden Schaden an iPhoto hinterlassen wird....! Aber diese Zeilen und warnenden Worte müssen heute einfach sein :-(....

* Eine, wenn nicht so gar DIE zwingende Vorraussetzung für die nachfolgenden Schritte ist die Verfügbarkeit eines hochauflösenden (z.B. in 72dpi) Fotos Deiner Digicam. Du findest das am einfachsten über die Homepage des Herstellers, dort z.B. unter Menüpunkten wie "Presseinformationen" bzw. "Pressefotos", oder aber auf Webseiten welche ein detailliertes Review Deiner Kamera durchgeführt haben.

Die Vorarbeiten:
* Backup der Anwendung iPhoto durch das erstellen einer Kopie der Applikation in Deinem "Programme" Ordner (oder wo auch immer sonst Du iPhoto installiert hast)
* Überprüfe ob Du Punkt 1. durchgeführt hast... ;-)
Um das große Image zu erstellen:
* Mache den Hintergrund Deines Kamerabildes weiß
* Ändere die Größe des Bildes auf 59x58 Pixel
* Setze den weißen Hintergrund auf Transparent
* Speichere das Bild als "camera.tif" (LZW TIFF, mit Alpha Channel zur Beibehaltung der Transparenz)

Um das kleine Image zu erstellen:
* Verwende das Bild "camera.tif" als Bildquelle (z.B. als Kopie)
* Ändere die Größe des Bildes auf 20x20 Pixel
* Speichere das Bild als "camera_small.tif" (LZW TIFF, mit Alpha Channel zur Beibehaltung der Transparenz)

Hinweis:
Ich habe für die Arbeiten an den Bilddateien Photoshop Elements 2.0 bzw. meinen persönlichen Favouriten GraphicConverter verwendet. Selbstverständlich sollte auch jedes andere Grafikprogramm dazu in der Lage sein - lediglich bezgl. der Abspeicherung der *.tif Datei mit dem transparenten Hintergrund ist Vorsicht geboten da es hier teilweise zu Überraschungen kommen kann - genau: der Hintergrund ist schwarz oder grau aber nicht transparent :-(...

Die Anpassungen an iPhoto selbst:
* Beende iPhoto
* Überprüfe erneut ob Du Punkt 1. der Vorarbeiten (siehe oben) durchgeführt hast... ;-)
* Wechsle in den Finder und in den Ordner "Programme" (oder wohin auch immer sonst Du iPhoto installiert hast)
* Zeige den Packetinhalt an - rechter Mausklick (bzw. Ctrl. und Mausklick) auf iPhoto und dann "Paketinhalt anzeigen" (es öffnet sich ein neues Finder-Fenster)
* Wechsle in dem neuen Finder-Fenster zu dem Ordner "Contents/Resources"
* Sicher die Images "camera.tif" und "camera_small.tif" als Kopie unter "camera_original.tif" und "camera_small_original.tif"
* Kopiere die in den beiden vorangegangenen Schritten erstellen Images in dieses Verzeichnis - Du mußt das Ersetzen der beiden Originaldateien bestätigen!

Überprüfe das Ergebnis Deines iPhoto Customizings:
* Starte iPhoto
* Wechsle in den Tab "Importieren" - eh voilà Du solltest jetzt das neue Image von Deiner Digicam sehen... :-)

Meine Images als *.gif Export und *.jpg Vorlage

item.title: Münchner Schlittenberge - Der Blomberg
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Wie und wo man(n) rund um München zum Winterrodeln gehen kann.

Wir waren neulich beim Schlittenfahren auf der Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg. Was soll ich sagen: cool war's... :-)) Da wir uns zunächst mühsam die besten Winterrodelstrecken rund um München zusammensuchen mussten :-( habe ich hier für Euch zum einen die Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg vorgestellt und zum anderen interessante und hilfreiche Links rund um das Thema "Schlittenfahren rund um München" zusammengestellt (...bitte keine Kommentare zu der Fotoqualität - ich weiß es selbst, hatte aber nur mein P800-Fotohandy dabei). Hope it helps...!

Die Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg

Die Anreise...


Die Talstation der Blomberg-Bahn.

Der Blomberg liegt bei Bad Tölz. Aus München kommst Du entweder über die Salzburger-Autobahn A8, Ausfahrt "Holzkirchen" und dann die B318 oder die Garmischer-Autobahn A95, Ausfahrt Wolfratshausen, Seeshaupt oder Sindelsdorf nach Bad Tölz. In Bad Tölz dann einfach der Beschilderung "Blomberg-Bahn" folgen. Auf der Internetseite der Blomberg-Bahn findest Du einen nützlichen(!) Link zu einem Routenplaner von Map24.com.

...der Aufstieg...


Die Wirtschaftsstraße zum Berggasthof "Blomberghaus".

Links neben der Talstation endet zum einen die Winterrodelbahn zum anderen beginnt hier die Wirtschaftsstraße zum Berggasthof "Blomberghaus" welche geradezu zum Aufstieg einlädt - naja, mehr oder weniger... ;-).
Nein, wir nehmen *nicht* den Sessellift - vielleicht für die zweite Tour...
Der Aufstieg dauert bei durchschnittlicher Kondition 1,5 Stunden und ist für Jung und Alt gleichermaßen geeignet. Ganz ehrlich: wer da nicht raufkommt sollte *dringend* mal über seine körperliche Fitness nachdenken...

...Unterwegs...


Unterwegs auf dem Wirtschaftsweg zum "Blomberghaus".

Irgendwann, auf dem Weg zu dem Berggasthof, stellt man(n) sich dann (doch) unweigerlich die Frage: "Warum haben wir eigentlich nicht den Sessellift genommen?" ...aber dann siegt doch wieder das Wissen um das bevorstehende Erfolgserlebnis - naja, und dann ist da ja auch noch der Sieg über den inneren Schweinehund!

...das Ziel?...

Und dann, nach 1,5 Stunden - das Ziel?


Das Gaststättenschild des Berggasthof "Blomberghaus".

...Brotzeit...


Der Berggasthof "Blomberghaus".

In dem "Blomberghaus" bekommt man neben deftiger bayerischer Hüttenkost (lecker und nicht zu teuer) auch des verdiente Glas "Manna".
Hier kann man(n) sich auch Mut für die nun unweigerlich bevorstehende Talfahrt holen - in jedem Fall jedoch aufwärmen und die durchgeschwitzten Klamotten trocknen.

...und schliesslich die Abfahrt :-))


Auf der Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg.

Dieses Foto ist eigentlich auch wieder selbstsprechend, oder?
Leider war bei unserem Besuch die Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg nicht ganz bis zur Talstation befahrbar und auch die Strecke an sich bereits deutlich durch die vielen begeisterten Rodler gekennzeichnet - aber a Gaudi war's trotzdem.
Wir werden auf jeden Fall wiederkommen...!

Linksammlung

Winterrodeln rund um München

Und hier noch die versprochene Linkliste:
• Rodeln.com - Deutschland
• Rodel-Tipp.de
• private Homepage von Robert Widhopf (...über das Design der Site reden wir mal nicht!)

item.title: Münchner Schlittenberge - Am Spitzingsee
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Wie und wo man(n) rund um München zum Winterrodeln gehen kann.

Nachdem ich in dem ersten Artikel der Reihe "Schlittenfahren rund um München" über die Winterrodelbahn am Blomberg berichtet habe, möchte ich Euch heute von einer noch **viel besseren** Location - in unseren Augen sogar von DER Rodelstrecke in der Nähe Münchens - berichten, welche wir in diesem Winter (2003/ 2004) bereits mehr als 4x besucht haben - stets mit steigender Begeisterung: der Rodelstrecke am Spitzingsee, genauer bei der Unteren und Oberen Firstalm.

Wie kommt man(n) an den Spitzingsee?

Mit Hilfe der nebenstehenden Anfahrtskizze sollte diese Frage leicht zu beantworten sein...


Anfahrtskizze München - Spitzingsee

Auf zur Tour 1...

Blick auf die Untere Firstalm, fotografiert von der Oberen Firstalm

Einmal angekommen liegen dem Rodel-Enthusiasten zwei unterschiedliche - in Kombination sogar drei - Routen zu Füssen - und das ist wörtlich gemeint, den ohne einen (kleinen) Aufstieg läuft hier nichts :-)....

Tour 1: Vom Parkplatz am Skilift zur Unteren Firstalm und dann Abfahrt mit dem Schlitten auf der verschneiten und vereisten(?!) Straße zurück zum Parkplatz. Diese Tour bietet noch zwei Varianten an:

Variante a) Aufstieg von der Unteren Firstalm zur Oberen Firstalm und dann diesen Aufstieg wieder hinabrodeln.

Variante b) Aufstieg von der Unteren Firstalm zur Oberen Firstalm und dann die Wirtschaftsstraße von der Oberen Firstalm zum Spitzing-Sattel hinabrodeln.

Oder wie wäre es mit der Tour 2?


Blick auf die Obere Firstalm, fotografiert von der Unteren Firstalm

Aufstieg direkt vom Spitzing-Sattel zur Oberen Firstalm über eine breite aber etwas steilere Wirtschaftsstraße als in Tour 1 - aber je steiler der Aufstieg umso rasanter die Abfahrt ;-)...! Auch in dieser Tour geht die Abfahrt wieder die Straße des Aufstiegs hinunter.

Oder doch besser die Tour 3?

Die von uns zuletzt mit der größten Begeisterung unternommene Tour verbindet die Vorzüge beider Strecken miteinander:
zunächst Aufstieg vom Parkplatz am Skilift zur Unteren Firstalm und weiter zur Oberen Firstalm - dieser Aufstieg ist etwas weniger Steil und damit zum "warm werden" besonders geeignet - mit anschliessender Abfahrt über die Wirtschaftsstraße der Oberen Firstalm zum Spitzing-Sattel
... und dann nocheinmal Aufstieg vom Spitzing-Sattel direkt zur Oberen Firstalm und anschliessend wieder diese Strecke - weil die bessere(!) zurück zum Spitzing-Sattel. Als einziger Nachteil bleibt der Rückweg zum Parkplatz am Skilift zu nennen... aber der hilft sich wieder in die Geschwindigkeit eines Zweibeiners einzufinden - nach den rasanten Abfahrten auf dem Schlitten ;-))...


Abfahrt auf der Wirtschaftsstraße der Oberen Firstalm

Und hier noch einige weitere Winter-Impressionen vom Spitzingsee

...leider nur mir meinem P800 aufgenommen und darum in schlechter Qualität :-(









Interessante und nützliche Links

...zu aktuellen Webcam Bildern und Wetterinformationen rund um den Spitzingsee
http://www.schliersee.de/
http://www.schliersbergalm.de/
http://www.skischule-spitzingsee.de/
http://www.spitzingsee.com/

item.title: Getting Connected: Zune vs. iPod - guess who is the winner?!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The following quote - that I've read via
Michael J.'s Notio
(
Getting Connected
) - made me smile sooooo... much! Enjoy!
"Classic Steve Jobs
quote
:
Microsoft has announced its new iPod competitor, Zune. It says that this device is all about building communities. Are you worried?
In a word, no. I've seen the demonstrations on the Internet about how you can find another person using a Zune and give them a song they can play three times. It takes forever. By the time you've gone through all that, the girl's got up and left! You're much better off to take one of your earbuds out and put it in her ear. Then you're connected with about two feet of headphone cable.
The guy sure knows how to give good media."

item.title: What?! PawSense: Catproof your computer (Windows-only)...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
At first I was asking myself: which date do we have - april 1th? But after cross-reading Michael's post I heared my self saying "YES" - ending up with a *big* healthy smile early in the morning - of course, especially for the last sentence :-)...
Although I don't have a cat myself (at the moment!) I know from my past experience with "Willi" what this tool is for - actually I know _to good_ ;-).
"
PawSense
: Catproof your computer. When cats walk or climb on your keyboard, they can enter random commands and data, damage your files, and even crash your computer. This can happen whether you are near the computer or have suddenly been called away from it. PawSense is a software utility that helps protect your computer from cats. It quickly detects and blocks cat typing, and also helps train your cat to stay off the computer keyboard. Of course, Windows-only. Everyone knows Mac cats are much better trained and there's no market for remedial catproofing software."
(Via
Michael J.'s Notio
:
PawSense
.)

item.title: Man on the escalator
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Something I'd really like to know: why does it feel strange to walk a broken escalator but does not feel the same walking a "normal" stairway?
Once in a while it happens to me that a escalator (that I have to pass on my way to work each day) is broken - not moving anymore. So I have to walk. Ok, as I'm usually in hurry to catch the underground I tend to walk down the escalator in any case - but: it feels really "strange" when it's not moving. Is this only because I'm so much used to it - sort of daily routine? Or is there more to it? Physics + psychology "mashed-up"? Or some total mystery in the end...?

item.title: Ups! Mass data import using del.icio.us API considered mal.icio.us by Yahoo!?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Today I finally found some time to move my web bookmarks from my personal
del.icio.us
clone (based on the open source tool
Scuttle
) to - well, you might have guessed it already:
del.icio.us
.
To be honest: I did not plan at all to live that long with a disconnected (or should I call it "unsocial"?) web-based bookmark application. Actually some time ago I just "played" a little with open source social bookmark toolsto figure out whether there is a good one to be used for a closed user group use case.
But back to the topic: so today I did use the approach
outlined by Markus Geiger
to move my bookmarks to
del.icio.us
:
  • XML export from Scuttle using the build-in api/post_all.php feature...
  • ...convert to XML that matches the del.icio.us APIs arguments (using a XSL(T) stylesheet for the transformation...
  • ... and a Python script to process the XML against api.del.icio.us.

Besides some small problems I encountered during the import (had to restart the script several times with reduced amount of data) the transition went very well! Thanks Markus!
But what a surprise when I tried to review the result in my browser
del.icio.us
:



Ok, I have to be fair:
  • I did upload ca. 500 bookmarks at once!!!!
  • ... and the Yahoo! support team did remove the temporary blocking in response to my support request within 10 minutes.
So not big thing after all - but quite interesting from a Web Worker point of view:
mass data manipulation might be considered mal.icio.us in a Software as a Service scenario!

item.title: Am I a geek if I find my self laughing about J Wynia's post: "If Marriage Was Strongly Typed . . ."???
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hmm, but does the answer really matter... ;-)
"If marriage was strongly typed, then asking my wife what time she's going to be home would return a timestamp. Similarly, asking if she'll be home for dinner would return a boolean. However, since marriage is a loosely typed language, both questions usually return an array. In the array is a list of the things she has to do before she can come home.
To properly parse this response, you actually need to estimate the duration of each item on the list, total the estimates, tack on about 20% for overrun and factor in the commute. Only when you've run the response through this wrapper method can you actually get the timestamp you were looking for. And, if you were looking for a boolean, you need to then compare your timestamp against the timestamp for dinner and see which is greater.
So, in essence, having a good marriage is like working in a loosely typed language and you've just got to have really good exception handling. Once you've built up a good library of wrapper methods for how your spouse communicates, things can just cruise right along and work smoothly. Or I guess you can throw an exception to be handled by the divorce() method. But that seems like a pretty bad approach."
(Via :
If Marriage Was Strongly Typed . . .--
The Glass is Too Big
.)

item.title: Thomas Edison, 1931: I'd put my money on solar
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This visionary and so(!) current thinking from a past green pioneer (Thomas Edison, 1931) makes me cry!!!

"In 1931, not long before he died, the inventor [Thomas Edison] told his friends Henry Ford and Harvey Firestone: 'I'd put my money on the sun and solar energy. What a source of power! I hope we don't have to wait until oil and coal run out before we tackle that.'"

Short prayer to myself: please let us (manking) listen more carefully to wise, visionary women and men while they are still alive or at least let's act, immediately - NOW!!!

(Via EcoGeek.org: Thomas Edison, 1931: "I'd Put My Money on Solar".)

item.title: Chumby - a personalized, always-on internet player
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Have to say that I really like both - the idea in general as well as the actual implementation of the chumby.

"The chumby is a compact device that displays useful and entertaining information from the web using your wireless internet connection. Always on, it shows — nonstop — what's online that matters to you."

The foundation of the chumby is a Linux-based, hackable mini computer. Besides the more kind of geeky hacking of the Linux stack the device can also be easily customized using - yes, of course you already guessed it - "widgets".

"A widget is a mini application that runs on your chumby. It can be a photo slideshow, animation, weather report, today's news headlines, webcam… and more."

Widgets can be easily shared on the chumby network.

"The Chumby Network is the free service that delivers widgets to your chumby."

item.title: Ever wanted to build your very own gadget? "Go, get the BUG!"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The BUG itself as well as the additional modules for the BUG, provided by it's manufactorer Bug Labs, is best descriped by the title of an CNET article:

"Bug Labs: The Lego of gadgets."
"It's a fully programmable and "hackable" Linux computer, equipped with a fast CPU, 128MB RAM, rechargeable battery, USB, Ethernet, and a small LCD with button controls. It also has a tripod mount because, well, why not? Each BUGbase houses four connectors for users to combine any assortment of BUGmodules to create their ultimate gadget."

Any hey, didn't we all love Lego in our younger days - or some of us even still today ;-)?

Broad hint: wouldn't this be a nice present? :-)

To bad that we have to wait quite some time until christmas...

item.title: Project Sun SPOT - small programmable object technology by Sun
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Project Sun SPOT - an initiative of Sun Microsystems Laboratories to make sure that the next generation of gadgets is based on Sun technology.
The Vision: Programming the Real-world
Inspiring Java developers to create a whole new breed of devices and technologies - and accelerating the growth of the "Internet of Things" (Project Sun SPOT)
What is a Sun SPOT device?

"The Sun SPOT Device is a small, wireless, battery powered experimental platform. It is programmed almost entirely in Java to allow regular programmers to create projects that used to require specialized embedded system development skills. The hardware platform includes a range of built-in sensors as well as the ability to easily interface to external devices." (Project Sun SPOT)
What I like about it?
Well, ...
  • first of all the vision itself: "accelerating the growth of the "Internet of Things".
  • the focus on Java: allowing "developers to write a program in Java, load it on a device, run it, and debug it with standard Java IDEs". Which is exactly why I personaly think the Google's Android will be a huge stakeholder in the mobile industry to come.
  • the open philosophie allowing to leverage the technology in which ever context you like, reaching from education to hoobyists.

item.title: Why Open Web Standards matter: The Watery Web
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Couldn't agree more to the essence of the following great metaphor that I stumbled upon while reading the post Deconstructing Rich Internet Applications by Matthew Gertner:

"Think of the web, of the Internet itself, as water. Proprietary platforms based on the web are ice cubes. They can, for a time, suspend themselves above the web at large. But over time, they only ever melt into the water. And maybe they make it better when they do."

(Via : Anil Dash: Blackbird, Rainman, Facebook and the Watery Web.)

item.title: Tour de Flex - Explore Flex Capabilities and Resources
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Tour de Flex is a Aodbe AIR-based desktop application for exploring Flex capabilities and resources, including the core Flex components, Adobe AIR and data integration, as well as a variety of third-party components, effects, skins, and more.

Tour de Flex has three primary purposes:

  • Provide non-Flex developers with a good overview of what is possible in Flex in a “look and see” environment
  • Provide Flex developers with an illustrated reference tool
  • Provide commercial and non-commercial Flex developers a place to showcase their work

Tour de Flex includes over 200 runnable samples, each with source code, links to documentation, and other details. Topics include the Flex Core Components, Flex Data Access, AIR Desktop Capabilities, Cloud APIs, Data Visualization, Mapping, and a growing collection of custom components, effects, skins, etc.

In case you're interested you can install the application with the following badge:

(Image Source: Wikipedia, some rights reserved)

Yesterday I recieved a notification that my "Personal Annual Report for 2008" for my Dopplr account is available and awaiting my download - but until now I didn't found time to actually have a look at it...

... only in order to learn:

  • You [me] took 8 trips in 2008, which added up to 43,602 km or 12% of the distance to the moon.
  • In 2008, you [me] spent 339 Day at Home [and] 27 travelling.

... resulting in:

Your personal velocity for 2008 was 4.97 km/h, which is about the same as a duck.

What's your velocity?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mine: 96 days travelling. Personal velocity for 2008 was 14.52 km/h, which is about the same as a chicken.

item.title: Optimism
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Optimism is a strategy for making a better future. Because unless you believe that the future can be better, it’s unlikely you will step up and take responsibility for making it so. If you assume that there’s no hope, you guarantee that there will be no hope. If you assume that there is an instinct for freedom, there are opportunities to change things, there’s a chance you may contribute to making a better world. The choice is yours.

Noam Chomsky

(Via swissmiss.)

Never heared of Noam Chomsky? Wikipedia is your friend...

item.title: Poetry - why the semantic web is a lot like love
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In case, like me, you never asked yourself if and what the semantic web and love could possibily have in common than there are big chances that a blog post by Scott Brinker well, ... might make you laugh :-):

10. It means different things to different people.

9. Those in it can bore everyone else to death talking about it.

8. Cynics insist there's no such thing.

7. It's straightforward in theory, messy in practice.

6. A few misinterpreted words can really screw things up.

5. You can invest a lot and not get any return.

4. Some people claim it, but don't really have it.

3. Some people have it, but don't want to disclose it.

2. The more people involved, the more complicated it gets.

1. When it works, beautiful relationships are established.

(Via chiefmartec.com, discovered on Twine.com.)

Some additional ones form the comment's section by MichalF:

- You can spend hours on the web looking for it

- It sounds distinctive in different languages (English/French/OWL/RDFS/N3...), but the meaning is always the same

- To make it last for longevity, it's important to keep the Sparkle/SPARQL.

item.title: Safari Microformats plugin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Safari Microformats plugin (Mac OS X Leopard 10.5+ only) notifies you when the author of the website has published Microformats and allows you to easily import hCards and hCalendars in Address Book and iCal.

How it works

When a hCard or hCalendar is present in the website you visit, the Microformats logo will be shown in the address bar.

Click on the logo, and a sheet opens, showing you all the Microformats. You can add them individually, or all at once.

At the bottom of the sheet, you can choose in which iCal calendar and Address Book group you wish to import the Microformats data. If you have installed Growl , a notification will be shown when you import data. Click the notification and iCal or Address Book will launch.

(Via Safari Microformats plugin.)

item.title: Released my personal linked data space into the wild
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I just published my personal URI/ linked data space at http://matthiasgeisler.net/id/me.

The space is built with Paget, an open source PHP framework for building linked data applications by Ian Davis. The framework requires the moriarty library (by Talis) and ARC2 (by semsol / Benjamin Nowack).

As Paget is currently only focussed on publishing data. Updates require touching the RDF resources - in my case static RDF files served by a custom, FileBasedUriSpace.

Lesson Learned: thanks to the great work of Ian and Benjamin a personal contribution to the Semantic Web, by exposing/ sharing personal linked data, is these days already pretty straight forward. And of course fun after all... :-).

Looking forward to integrate and ellaborate this experience into my book!

item.title: Why does the Semantic Web matter: a Video Presentation in 5 Minutes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:

...a revolution is happening in the structure of the web itself. It’s gentle and it’s powerful, it’s like tai-chi: you hardly know that is happening, but when it hits, it has a massive impact.

item.title: Mac: XML Nanny and XMLPalette - handy little helpers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In case you're - like me - at least every once in a while in favour of an application with GUI over the dominant shell/ terminal, you might find these two nice little Cocoa apps. come in handy while working with XML, DTD, XSD and XSL(T) on the Mac:

XML Nanny

XML Nanny is a free (as in beer) Cocoa application for Mac OS X Tiger that allows you to parse and validate local or remote XML documents against DTD, W3C XML Schema, RELAX NG, and Schematron schemas.
(Source: xmlnanny.com)

XSLPalette

The free, native, XSLT 2.0, XPath 2.0, and XQuery 1.0 debugging palette your favorite Mac OS X text editor has been missing.
(Source: ditchnet.org)

item.title: Mac: HTTP Client - your friend while (semantically) RESTing
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Speaking about nice little GUI helpers on the Mac: in case you're - again like me - a fan of REST for your (semantic) web application's software architecture you might enjoy working with Todd Ditchendorf’s HTTP Client.

A Mac OS X Leopard developer tool for debugging HTTP services by graphically creating & inspecting complex HTTP messages.
(Source: ditchnet.org)

The app. comes in particularly handy while exploring the semantic web's linked data spaces. E.g. in case you want to test with different Accept headers (JSON vs. XML/RDF) against your linked data space, e.g. my URI matthiasgeisler.net/id/me, built with Paget.

item.title: Sir Tim Berners-Lee: The next Web of open, linked data
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ok, let's practise: shout out loud Raw Data Now!

Good, and again... :-)

So, what's the bottom line?

Open is good, no doubt about that. And the concept will work right away with all things non private - actually it does already today. But we have to start considering about privacy concerns now in order to implement it as common practise in our day-to-day life.

But one step at a time... Raw Data Now!

item.title: Reserved Top Level DNS Names example.{com|net|org}
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I totally wasn't aware that the top level DNS names example.com, example.net and example.org, are reserved for use in documentation and therefore not available for registration (according to RFC 2606).

But there is actually a website published under these domain names:

Once again, what a wealth of information to be found in the W3C specification documents, e.g. the RDF/XML Syntax Specification.

item.title: How to tell spring is due with Twitter and Alfresco
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
It's as simple as three little steps:

  1. create a simple Twitter search with query 'Alfresco', e.g. with TweetDeck
  2. split and count the tweets in the result set into 'Alfresco' being mentioned as
    a) x=COUNT(related to Alfresco, the OSS ECM/ WCM) or
    b) y=COUNT(meaning 'in the open'; 'in the open air'; 'outside'; 'out of doors')
  3. Calc the ratio z=y/x

Here you go: the higher z the closer is spring! Or at least the better the weather has been the last 24h ;-)...

These are semanticdreamer's del.icio.us bookmarks for March 25th from 15:17 to 20:54:

  • Microformats Bookmarklet - a cross-browser bookmarklet. A click brings up an overlay window of all the hCards and hCalendars within the current page.
  • Talis Semantic Web Formats Converter - a web service for converting semantic web data from one format to another: RDF/XML, Turtle and RDF/JSON can all be converted into one another, converted to TriX, Exhibit/JSON, or RSS 1.0, or rendered as HTML.
  • Oomph - A Microformats Toolkit - a Microformats Toolkit: an Internet Explorer Add-in that finds Microformats on a page; a cross-browser HTML overlay built using JQuery that aggregates Microformats; a set of beautiful CSS styles for Microformats; and a Windows Live Writer plug-in written in WinForms for inserting hCards

item.title: Semantic Dreamer goes 'Oomph'
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I just incorporated a cross-browser HTML overlay to aggregate the Microformats used on my blog.

The overlay is triggered by YOU clicking on the little (gleaming on page load) button in the upper left corner of the site.

The overlay will "light up" Microformats used throught the site, aggregate and map the content (using Microsoft Virtual Earth) as well as provid options to export the data, e.g. hCalendar to Outlook, Google Calendar, Yahoo Calendar and Apple's iCal or hCard to Yahoo!, Outlook and Apple's Addressbook.

The overlay is built using JQuery and is part of the Consume track of Microsoft's Oomph toolkit.

About Oomph

Oomph: A Microformats Toolkit is for web developers, designers and users, making it easier to create, consume, and style Microformats. In short, Oomph makes consuming and producing content for the web just a little easier, more efficient, more fun.
(Source: visitmix.com/lab/oomph)

Especially in case your operating system is Windows you might want to check out the other features of the toolkit:

  • an Internet Explorer Add-in that finds Microformats on a page
  • a Windows Live Writer plug-in written in WinForms for inserting hCards

The Oomph's source code is available from the project site hosted on Microsoft's CodePlex: oomph.codeplex.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice - I blogged about this library on labs a while back - added a link to this post from the comments there

item.title: Go and scr.im your email address
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Scr.im is a simple but nicely built free service (currently in beta) to convert your email address into a short, cute and safe link that you can share on the web.

Why would you want to do this? Well, of course to get less spam! ;-)

How does it work? Instead of tricking around to obfuscate your email address with some nasty JavaScript hack people willing to email you will go to this URL (e.g. http://scr.im/matthias) that will reveal your email address, after a simple test that automated scripts and bots cannot pass.

item.title: Microsoft's Xbox 360 project Natal, truly amazing!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft Xbox 360 Project Natal

No Strings (or Controllers) Attached.
Introducing Project Natal, a revolutionary new way to play: no controller required. See a ball? Kick it, hit it, trap it or catch it. If you know how to move your hands, shake your hips or speak you and your friends can jump into the fun -- the only experience needed is life experience. (Source: Xbox 360 Microsoft Project Natal)

(via Twine)

item.title: Google did it again: Google Wave Rocks!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is truly amazingly hot stuff! ... and - again - incredibly well engineered!! Honestly, I can't wait to get my hands on Google Wave!

Actually I should say: Weaving and Surfing Waves! :-)

Google Wave is a new tool for communication and collaboration on the web, coming later this year. Watch the demo video below, sign up for updates and learn more about how to develop with Google Wave.
(Source: Google Wave Preview)

Resources

  • Google Wave Preview
  • waveprotocol.org - the homepage for the Google Wave Federation Protocol
  • Google Wave API

Update: Meanwhile I managed to "play" at least a little bit with the Wave Sandbox - using the 2nd test account of a generous colleague (thx M.!) - while still waiting for my Wave Developer Account request to be processed.
Pretty impressed by the Wave UI but also wondering what the transformation management strategy of Google will look like when Wave hits the average users, as Wave clearly requires quite some rethinking...

item.title: iPhone OS 3.0 Software-Update available - but not for immediate activation, grrrrr!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Download succeeded, but activation failed due to activation server temporality not available. Most probably overloaded - or should I say overwhelmed?!

... the downside of the iPhone being a huge success in a global community that is all about early adoption - even for software updates! ;-)

Update 18.06. I finally managed to install and activate the update early morning today - probably could have managed to do so late night yesterday as well, but after all didn't feel it's worth the price of feeling sleepy all day.

item.title: Enterprise Open Source Directory Establishes Advisory Board, me boarded
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The EOS directory is the leading online platform to help enterprises and organizations identify and evaluate Open Source technologies.

Intially launched by Optaros, about two years ago, the platform has been recently handed over Bruno von Rotz, initial sponsor of the initiative and well known Open Source specialist (follow Bruno on Twitter: accelIT).

In support to strengthen the neutral approach to ratings and selection of the technologies, the new EOS Directory Advisory and Expert Board has been established over the last weeks and announced today.

The Advisory and Expert Board will be both instrumental in guiding the future development of the EOS Directory Platform as well as in making sure that the content is accurate, relevant and fairly represented. (Source: EOS Directory Blog)

The initial member list of the EOS Directory Advisory and Expert Board - representing user and provider communities as well as international expert audiences - includes Aleksander Farstad, Cédric Walter, David Nüscheler, Gianugo Rabellino, Roberto Galoppini, Hannes Gassert, Hans Waarle, Joel Gardet, Matt Asay, Matthias Geisler, Michael Hanisch, Olivier Pépin, Raju Bitter, Ralf Hauser, Seth Gottlieb, Stephen Walli and Tiberiu Fustos.

During the next months the EOS Directory Platform will also be rejuvenated and updated to even better support Enterprises and Organizations in need for Open Source technologies’ selection and evaluation help. (Source: EOS Directory Blog

Hint: In addition to the EOS Directory in English, there’s also a German language PDF catalogue based on the same information, published under www.opensourcekatalog.com. (via robertogaloppini.net)

item.title: Semantic Web: schnell+kompakt (deutsch)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Über das Buch

Der Begriff "Semantic Web" beschreibt nicht eine einzelne Kerntechnologie, sondern vielmehr ein Konzept für die Symbiose aus mensch- und maschinenlesbarem Internet als Weiterentwicklung des heutigen WWW.

Das Buch führt in die Grundlagen und Bausteine des Semantischen Web ein und erläutert die Kernkonzepte RDF, RDF-Schema, OWL und SPARQL.

Der praktische Teil des Buches bietet einen schnellen Einstieg in den Einsatz der Technologien für die eigene Homepage oder Weblog und die Firmen-Webseite. Für die Beispiele werden gängige Webtechno-logien (XHTML, XML, JavaScript, PHP) und beliebte Open Source Softwareprodukte (Drupal, WordPress) verwendet.

Aus dem Inhalt
  • Begriffsdefinition und Syntaktische Grundlagen (XML, RDF)
  • Semantic Web Praxis (Mikroformate, RDFa, Linked Data)
  • Einfache Ontologien mit RDF-Schema (z.B. FOAF)
  • Web Ontologie Sprache OWL
  • RDF Anfragesprache SPARQL
  • PHP-Beispiele für Drupal und WordPress
Zielgruppe

IT-Manager, Content/Knowledge Manager, IT-Architekten, Projektleiter, Softwareentwickler, Webdesigner, Webmaster, Studenten

Beispiele

Hier in meinem Weblog finden sich die Beispiele aus dem Buch, nach Kapiteln gegliedert, als Quelltext und zum Download sowie  – wo sinnvoll möglich – auch als Online-Demo.

Wo kaufen

Das Buch kann direkt über den Verlag entwickler.press oder auf Amazon.de Online bestellt werden! :-)

item.title: Linus the parenting gold star - big smile!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I had a big, big smile while reading Linus Torvalds latest blog post titled Parenting gold star (?). Here is why - enjoy, as much as I did!:-)

One of his children, Celeste (8), was asked in Tae-Kwon-Do summer camp to write a letter home about how she is thankful to their parents.

She is starting like follows:

Celeste: "You buy me lunch, breakfast and dinner. You bought me animals to play with so I could have a lot of fun in my life."

... nice, fine so far...

Celeste: "You also let me bury them instead of flushing them down the toilet."

Well, yeah, something that does obviously really count for a child. As Linus states: premium parenting Clearly have to remeber this!

Linus: "Ooh, yeah! That's some premium parenting there. Gold stars all around!"

Closing clause:

Linus: "Of course, she has clearly forgotten about the fish. We did flush those."

(Via Linus' blog.)

item.title: "Project: CODE_RUSH": Great Video documentation about Netscape and Mozilla
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you're into software and the internet, enjoyed reading books like Weaving the Web: The Original Design and Ultimate Destiny of the World Wide Web by Its Inventor (by Tim Berners-Lee), Where Wizards Stay Up Late: The Origins of the Internet or Dreaming in Code (about the Chandler project) and Mozilla's Open-Source Software products like the browser Firefox or the email client Thunderbird are amongst the list of your favourite computer programs then - well chances are very high that you might enjoy the movie Project: CODE_RUSH. Relax and enjoy! :-)

"Code Rush [...] is an inside look at living and working in Silicon Valley at the height of the dot-com era. The film follows a group of Netscape engineers as they pursue at that time a revolutionary venture to save their company - giving away the software recipe for Netscape's browser in exchange for integrating improvements created by outside software developers." (Source: Project: CODE_RUSH)

(Via t3n Magazin.)

item.title: Squirrel in Focus - awesome photo of once in a lifetime moment
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This photo totally made my week :-):

Melissa Brandts: "My husband and I were exploring Lake Minnewanka in Banff National Park, Canada, when we stopped for a timed picture of the two of us. We had our camera set up on some rocks and were getting ready to take the picture when this curious little ground squirrel appeared, became intrigued with the sound of the focusing camera and popped right into our shot! A once in a lifetime moment! We were laughing about this little guy for days!"
(Source for Text + Photo: Daily Dozen - National Geographic Magazine)

(Via swissmiss.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Canadas Squirrels take the chance if they can get on a photo ;) its a awesome lucky shot!

item.title: How-to Install Rails 3.0 Beta on OS 10.5.8 Leopard
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
While I did most of my recent web dev projects in PHP5 I still follow the development of Ruby on Rails ...on it's path to a stable version 3.0 release.

So no wonder that I had to get my hands dirty with the just recently released Rails 3.0 Beta.

While I still own a 12" PowerBook with OS X 10.5.8 Leopard (latest OS X PPC release) I needed to get rails-3.0.0.beta running on this machine - of course ;-)

1. Upgrade to Ruby 1.8.7 with RubyGems

As at least Ruby 1.8.7 is required by Rails 3.0 I decided to use MacPorts (prerequisite!) to upgrade Ruby version 1.8.6 as shipped with OS X Leopard.

sudo port install ruby rb-rubygems sudo gem update --system source ~/.profile Satellit:~ matthias$ ruby -v ruby 1.8.7 (2009-06-12 patchlevel 174) [powerpc-darwin9]

2. Install Rails 3.0 Beta (rails-3.0.0.beta) along with the required dependencies

sudo gem install i18n tzinfo builder memcache-client rack rack-test rack-mount erubis mail text-format thor bundler sqlite3-ruby sudo gem install rails --pre

3. Create Rails app. and start the server

Satellit:~ matthias$ rails rails3beta-test Satellit:~ matthias$ cd rails3beta-test Satellit:~ matthias$ rails server

Inspired by Silumesii Maboshe.

item.title: CouchDB, finally relaxing!!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The other day(s) I found myself relaxing while coding away a pet project (a tiny schemaless personal project, activity and knowledge management web application) leveraging CouchDB and jQuery.

"CouchDB is a document-oriented database that can be queried and indexed in a MapReduce fashion using JavaScript [...] provides a RESTful JSON API than can be accessed from any environment that allows HTTP requests [...] is written in Erlang [...]" (Source: couchdb.apache.org)

Check out CouchApp in order to write CouchDB applications by using just JavaScript and HTML.

"CouchApp is designed to structure standalone CouchDB application development for maximum application portability. CouchApp is a set of scripts and a jQuery plugin designed to bring clarity and order to the freedom of CouchDB's document-based approach." (Source: CouchApp)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Matthias, I would have liked to read your thoughts about couchdb and semantic markup in json format. Or do these two areas stand completely separate in your view?

Good question, happy to share my thoughts on: I assume you're referring to RDF/JSON, a serialization of RDF in JavaScript Object Notation (e.g. see inputs to the JSON RDF Task Force within the W3C RDF Working Group) - right? A CouchDB document consists of named fields - is simply a JSON object - is accessible via a RESTful JSON API. That said, CouchDB is a perfect fit for any JSON document, including RDF/JSON. On the contrary, if you compare CouchDB to an average Triplestore you'll find some bits missing: no OOTB support for SPARQL and OWL - to name a view. In my eyes RDF/JSON is a very interesting and important serialization for RDF. And depending on your (application) requirements CouchDB can be a good fit, playing nicely along with RDF/JSON... _IF_ you're not in need for a dedicated Triplestore. Some examples for a fitting type of application could be found in the domain of Semantic (Web) Content Management Systems, Mobile Semantic Applications, Semantic Applications that require Replication/ Synchronisation. Now, I'm curious about your thoughts Karl?

Matthias:
First, I have been combing the web for experiments that combine these 3: json, couchDB, and RDF. This is a very concrete search - I want an example, even a tutorial how to do it. I don't consider myself advanced enough to do it, but I may have to...
In my mind, all non-trivial data a web site handles should be subject to ontological definition, not as an immediate need, but a long-term one. So beyond this urgent concrete goal I have thrown your way, I will try to share some of my thoughts on web philosophy.
It is as if these three technologies can be made to represent three axes in the mind space of our current situation. Json is the standard of WHATWG, which radically departed from XHMTL, as we all now can only vaguely remember because two years have passed. The threat came from Adobe, and others, who positioned themselves to privatize the visual web. Json and HTML5 was and is instrumental in giving open source the breathing room needed - mainly to develop Canvas. Json and its dependent technologies like jQuery are as crucial to this effort as XML was to the (failed) W3C effort at standardization of HTML in preparation for RDF and the Semantic web.
The fact that RDF-centric developers can barely communicate with json-oriented developers is a scandal to the open source community members who understand the stakes for the future of web-centric, ubiquitous, visual, multi-dimensional, intelligent computing.
CouchDB is also representative of a trend away from the older highly structured data approaches represented by RDBMS and in many ways, RDF Triple Stores. It's emphasis on map-reduce is a departure from declarative query languages such as SQL and XPath. It's primary scripting language is simply functional javascript. This trend is, in my mind, a bit post-modern: we now define our data implicitly in the contextual manner it is used, not explicitly, before it is even used.
In the days when XHTML was still the goal, there was frequent discussion about how web development would dimply coalesce with semantic practices - web authors would simply start tagging their data correctly, and everything else needed to create the semantic web would naturally follow. I notice nobody talks that way about json - effectively XML's replacement by an overwhelming consensus. Why is that?
This is a critical point in time. The RDF/semantic world is embroiled in their usual wrestling over how to implement RDF/Json. The WHATWG world is largely ignoring them. It would seem a Grand Unifying Theory (and practice) is very close, but not yet visible.
See this: https://github.com/webr3/js3#readme

item.title: Recipe: How-to install CouchDB 0.11.0 from source on OS X
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Prerequisite: MacPorts installed and SVN client at hand - I prefer a UI and therefore use Versions.

  • sudo port install autoconf automake libtool
  • sudo port install icu erlang spidermonkey curl
  • svn co http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/couchdb/tags/0.11.0 couchdb-0.11.0-src
  • cd couchdb-0.11.0-src
  • ./bootstrap
  • ./configure
    >> You have configured Apache CouchDB, time to relax.
  • make && sudo make install
    >> You have installed Apache CouchDB, time to relax.
  • Start the CouchDB server by running: sudo -i couchdb -b
    >> Apache CouchDB has started, time to relax.
  • To check that everything has worked, point your web browser to: http://127.0.0.1:5984/_utils/index.html

Usefull resources:

  • CouchDB: The Definitive Guide - Part VI. Appendix Installing from Source
  • Apache Couch DB Source Code

item.title: Recipe: How-to install Pandoc on OS X 10.6.x (Snow Leopard)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In case you wonder how-to install Pandoc, the "universal document converter" on OS X Snow Leopard...

... the secret sauce: go for Haskell Platform installer instead of following your standard (assumption!) installation approach using MacPorts.

The steps:

  1. First install Haskell Platform.
  2. cabal update
  3. cabal install cabal-install
  4. cabal install pandoc
  5. Update your ~/.profile file with export PATH=/Users/[USERNAME]/.cabal/bin:$PATH and read in with source ~/.profile.

What is Pandoc? Great you asked! ;)

Pandoc can read markdown and (subsets of) reStructuredText, HTML, and LaTeX, and it can write plain text, markdown, reStructuredText, HTML, LaTeX, ConTeXt, PDF, RTF, DocBook XML, OpenDocument XML, ODT, GNU Texinfo, MediaWiki markup, groff man pages, and S5 HTML slide shows. PDF output (via LaTeX) is also supported with the included markdown2pdf wrapper script.
-- Source and more details: johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc

item.title: Wordle.net - word cloud from del.icio.us tags
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The word cloud below is created using the tags of my del.icio.us bookmarks. I really like this type of visual representation of the things I dig :-).

"Wordle is a toy for generating "word clouds" from text that you provide. The clouds give greater prominence to words that appear more frequently in the source text. You can tweak your clouds with different fonts, layouts, and color schemes. The images you create with Wordle are yours to use however you like. You can print them out, or save them to the Wordle gallery to share with your friends." (Source: wordle.net)

According to the service's Terms of use you're entitled to use your Wordle in any way you choose - so GO, create your own Wordle by either...

  • ...pasting in a bunch of text.
  • ...providing the URL of any blog, blog feed, or any other web page that has an Atom or RSS feed.
  • ... or - like me - entering a del.icio.us user name to see the tags.

item.title: Wise Words abouy Life by Steve Jobs
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Wise Words by Steve Jobs:

"[...] Life can be much broader, once you discover one simple fact, and that is that everything around you that you call life was made up by people that were no smarter than you. And you can change it, you can influence it, you can build your own things that other people can use. Once you learn that, you’ll never be the same again."

(Via swissmiss.)
